将刻意练习应用于职业生涯所需的三个要素。

《培养稀有且有价值的技能的关键》一文首先出现在Scott H Young上。

;

在过去的三课中，我讨论了关注推动人们成功的职业资本的重要性、解释稀有且有价值的技能为何如此重要的供需逻辑，以及正确识别前进道路的至关重要性。这样你就不会因为做错事而精疲力竭。

今天，我想谈谈如何才能掌握在职业生涯中蓬勃发展所需的技能。

安德斯·爱立信和刻意练习的遗产

很少有心理学家比安德斯·埃里克森（ Anders Ericsson ）对专业知识研究的贡献更大。他研究世界级表演的工作始于一项简单的记忆研究。

数字跨度任务长期以来一直是认知心理学研究的主要内容。这些都是简单的任务，向受试者提供一系列数字，然后要求他们回忆尽可能多的数字。此类任务的一个著名发现是，大多数人可以回忆起五到九个数字。

通常，受试者在这项任务上几乎没有练习。然而，爱立信只研究一个主题，并在多次会议中重复相同的任务。结果？受试者的数字广度呈爆炸式增长——在长时间的训练结束后，他可以回忆起100 多个数字。

在这个特定的受试者案例中，他发明了一种利用跑步时间（他是一名狂热的跑步者）的助记系统来回忆比他的记忆通常允许的更多的数字。

这段经历使埃里克森开始了长期的职业生涯，研究大量集中练习对人类表现的影响。从医生到音乐家，各行各业的专家都可以通过这些持续的努力取得令新手难以想象的成就。

当我和卡尔·纽波特开始研究最佳表演者时，爱立信的研究为我们提供了重要的灵感。考虑到世界一流的技能和出色的职业生涯之间的联系，我们有兴趣了解这种刻意练习的模式如何应用于实验室、网球场或音乐学院之外——它如何应用于不进行此类练习的专业领域这不是常态。

将刻意练习应用于办公室

获得任何复杂技能都需要三个基本要素：

  1. 您需要了解该技能如何发挥作用。这主要来自于从其他人的示例中学习，因此您不会重新发明轮子，而是使用当前的最佳实践。
  2. 你需要大量练习。练习可以让你更快更自动地运用技能。埃里克森对刻意练习的痴迷源于通过大量练习似乎消除了对人类表现的硬性心理限制。
  3. 您需要纠正反馈。了解一项技能的工作原理并经常进行操作通常不足以获得非常好的效果——通常需要纠正反馈来识别你做错了什么并提供替代方案以继续改进。

爱立信对刻意练习的定义包括远离生产性工作需求的集中培训课程。在这些课程中，您将关注您表现的一个关键方面。几乎总是需要辅导，因为否则很难获得足够的纠正反馈。

这种刻意练习的定义在严格控制的高水平领域（例如国际象棋、音乐或体育）中非常有意义。但是，正如一位前最佳表现学生所说，当你的工作“基本上是整天回复电子邮件”时，你该怎么做才能变得更好呢？

设计刻意练习项目

真实环境中的专业技能与实验室研究中高度控制的变量不同。因此，在培养稀有且有价值的职业技能时，获得爱立信认为对世界级技能发展至关重要的刻意练习通常很困难。

同时，如果我们想加速自己的职业生涯，就需要避免陷入简单积累资历的陷阱。许多从业者，即使是拥有多年经验的从业者，也并不是特别熟练。尽管拥有多年的经验，但如果缺乏合适的培训环境，他们的技能可能会停止进步。

卡尔和我在《最佳表演者》中解决这一困境的方法是指导学生设计一个刻意的练习项目。此类项目结合了几个要素：

  1. 它应该是有重点和具体的——不仅仅是日常工作，而是一些“额外”的东西，可以迫使你的技能达到更高的水平。
  2. 您应该有机会通过示例进行研究，看看如何做到最好。自己弄清楚所有事情是很慢的，所以一个好的项目首先要清楚地了解你想要提高的技能是如何发挥作用的。
  3. 您应该能够获得可以推动您进步的明确反馈。

设计一个好的项目并非易事。您需要找到适合您想要发展的职业资本的东西。然后，您需要专注于您的项目，以便能够进行改进，同时保持其与您的工作生活相关。最后，你需要做这项工作。每一步都有其挑战。

然而，正如我们在过去的优秀学生中看到的那样，学生可以在此类项目中取得成功，而且他们新开发的技能可以帮助他们在工作中取得进步。学生们利用项目找到了新的工作，获得晋升和加薪，并提高了自己的专业技能。

我希望您喜欢我们的课程“最佳表现者”中的这个系列课程。在为期八周的完整课程中，我们更详细地介绍了如何建立您热爱的职业。我希望您考虑参加我们的下一次会议！

以下是最好的职业研究策略，可确保您的刻意练习不会陷入死胡同。

这篇文章在你工作精疲力尽之前，就这样做吧，首先出现在Scott H Young上。

;

在前两节课中，我分享了为什么在尝试效仿成功人士的成就时应该关注他们的职业资本而不是他们的个人怪癖。接下来，我应用供需经济模型来理解为什么有些人能够通过谈判获得丰厚的职业福利——金钱、自主权、灵活性——而另一些人却不能。

职业资本，尤其是稀有且有价值的技能，是找到您喜欢的工作的起点。但你如何获得它们呢？

一个诱人的答案就是努力工作。虽然成功确实需要努力工作，而且大多数成功人士往往都是努力工作的人，但努力工作并不能保证成功。

虽然如果不努力工作几乎不可能培养稀有且有价值的技能，但很多人努力工作，但仍然没有丰厚的职业资本。因此，尽管他们有着良好的职业道德，但他们却无法获得与真正的顶尖员工相同的福利。

卡尔和我从 8 年以上表现最佳者那里学到的第一堂课

你可以通过培养能够带来有用的职业资本的技能来避免这个陷阱，因此当我们开始进行“最佳表演者”课程的第一次迭代时，卡尔·纽波特和我就想到了如何培养这些技能的具体细节。

我们已经对人们如何培养技能有了一个想法——率先提出刻意练习概念的心理学家安德斯·埃里克森（Anders Ericsson）花了数十年的时间研究掌握困难技能所需的脑力劳动。有针对性的练习，尤其是在教练的监督下，可以使你的技能增长还是停滞不前。

然而，当我们进行该课程的第一堂课时，我们注意到一些不同的事情：大多数人不知道他们需要培养哪些技能！

更糟糕的是，许多人似乎倾向于那些与真正能带来改变的东西无关的技能。人们似乎热衷于提高工作起来很有趣的技能——这是一个费力的项目（但不是太难），这样他们就能感觉到自己正在做一些需要改进的事情，但他们并没有在最重要的事情上工作。

为了乐趣而学习并没有什么错。但如果你的目标是建立职业资本，这种方法可能会适得其反。您可以花费数月的时间来提高与雇主、客户或消费者真正想要的东西没有直接关系的技能。

没有捷径，但有很多死胡同

意识到许多人在刻意的练习努力中陷入了死胡同，卡尔和我调整了课程的下一次迭代：在进入密集的技能建设工作之前，我们让学生研究他们的职业道路实际上是如何运作的。一旦他们理解了这一点，他们就能更好地理解哪些项目可以让他们朝着正确的方向前进，哪些项目是浪费时间。

进行此类研究很棘手。您需要了解的大部分内容都过于具体，无法写在书本或文章中，因此去图书馆或网络搜索通常会不够。相反，你需要与人交谈。然而，与取得成功的人交谈同样会令人沮丧！即使是那些已经积累了一套令人惊讶的特定技能的人，当被问及他们是如何做到这一点时，也常常会退回到有关努力工作价值的通用陈词滥调。

然而，正确地进行这项研究是至关重要的。在开始行走之前了解道路可以帮助您避免人们在职业生涯发展时陷入的常见陷阱：

  1. 获得无人关心的硕士学位。
  2. 当您需要人际交往能力时，请致力于技术技能。
  3. 没有找到在简历中展示你的技能的正确方法。
  4. 没有认识到哪些工作是职业发展机会，哪些工作是死胡同。

多年来与许多学生合作后，卡尔和我发现，最适合寻求此建议的人是在你正在考虑的职业方向上领先你 2 到 3 步的人。这些人最近升职了，所以他们的信息是最新的，并且在他们的脑海中是新鲜的。

一旦你找到并联系了这些人，你需要让他们告诉你他们是如何到达现在的位置的——这是非常困难的。早些时候，卡尔和我发现我们的学生只是向这些人寻求建议。虽然这看起来是显而易见的举动，但它几乎从来没有奏效。你需要像记者一样报道这个人的职业转型故事，而不是直接询问——弄清楚他们在哪里、何时、什么以及为什么实现了你目前正在考虑的职业飞跃。

这两项行动，即找到在你的职业生涯中比你领先 2 或 3 步的人，并对他们进行采访，以了解他们到底做了什么（而不仅仅是他们想要分享的建议），可以帮助你缩小你需要的职业资本要素的范围。投资，你可以忽略未来。

在下一课也是最后一课中，我将分享我的想法，即从识别有价值的技能到真正擅长这些技能。之后，卡尔和我将为新的会议开设“最佳表演者” 。如果我分享的想法引起了您的共鸣，我想您会喜欢我们将它们付诸实践的完整课程。

应用 Econ 101 来了解为什么有些人拥有出色的工作，而另一些人却没有。

这篇文章 《解释你是否会拥有伟大职业生涯的简单经济理论》首先出现在Scott H Young上。

;

在上一课中，我解释了为什么关注不相关的细节会掩盖职业成功的真正驱动力：职业资本。

但职业资本和伟大职业之间的联系并不总是那么明显。为什么汽车经销店老板的收入往往高于护士或教师？为什么大多数人都以艺术家的身份艰难谋生，但将鲨鱼标本放入水箱的人却价值近 5 亿美元？

你是否会拥有一个伟大的职业生涯的基本答案可以用供给和需求的简单经济概念来理解。

供需思维应用于您的工作生活

我们先从需求开始。

经济学家绘制一条向下倾斜的曲线来表示人们在给定价格下想要多少东西。纵轴是某物的成本，横轴是有多少人愿意以每个价格购买该东西。在其他条件相同的情况下，当价格较高时，愿意（或有能力）购买某物的人就会减少。

这条曲线可以作为一种有用的方式来思考你为他人提供的价值。在就业市场上，如果人们愿意为此付出更多，你的职业资本就很有价值。一组更高价值的职业资本可以通过向右移动的需求曲线来表示——更多的人希望以任何特定的价格拥有你的职业资本。

但需求并不是全部。水是生命所必需的，而钻石则不然。但水便宜是因为水供应充足，钻石贵是因为钻石供应稀缺。

同样，您职业生涯的供给曲线可以设想为愿意为特定工资（纵轴）提供职业资本（横轴）的人数。随着价格上涨，更多的人愿意提供人们想要的技能、人脉、声誉和其他资产。

供给曲线还可以衡量您特定职业资本的稀缺性。教师和护士的收入比许多汽车经销店老板的收入要低，因为有更多的人拥有教育孩子或担任护士的职业资产，而不是拥有可以出售大量汽车的大地。

在正常运作的市场中，需求曲线和供给曲线之间的交点反映了给定产品的价格和销售数量。如果需求高而供应低，价格就会上涨。

在职业环境中，职业资本的回报取决于有多少人重视它，以及有多少其他人可以提供它。这意味着要拥有良好的职业地位，你需要既稀有又有价值的资产。

这种想法不仅仅适用于你赚了多少钱。当然，拥有稀有而宝贵的职业资产的人可以将其转化为更高的收入。但这些资产也可以作为你可能想要的任何其他东西的谈判点：假期、有趣的项目、专业自主权等等。您热爱的职业和高薪职业可能并不总是同一回事，但它们都是通过稀有且宝贵的职业资本实现的。

作为一种心理模型，我发现供需思维非常有用，但它忽略了很多重要因素。价格上限、垄断雇主、限制会员资格的专业行会等等都使这一基本模式变得复杂。然而，它仍然是思考您可以从事的职业类型的良好基准。

培养稀有且有价值的技能

正如上一课所讨论的，技能通常是建立职业资本的最佳起点。声誉和人脉往往是在出色的工作之后，而不是先于出色的工作，因此最好的起点是培养支持出色工作的技能。

这种观点将问题从如何建立有价值的职业重新定义为：如何获得稀有且有价值的技能？

这是我和卡尔在第一次开始构建“最佳表现者”课程时提出的开场问题。在接下来的两节课中，我将分享近十年来与数千名学生研究这个问题的两项主要发现。我们正在准备下周开始的新会议。如果您有兴趣建立真正推动伟大职业生涯的职业资本，我希望您加入我们。

为什么我们会痴迷于无关紧要的个性怪癖，而不是真正推动一个人成功的因素？

帖子《谁在乎沃伦·巴菲特午餐吃什么？》首次出现在Scott H Young上。

;

我最讨厌的是自助建议，它痴迷于不相关的个​​性怪癖，而不是一个人成功的真正驱动力。

  • 对冲基金亿万富翁雷·达里奥每天冥想四十分钟。
  • 蒂姆·费里斯 (Tim Ferriss) 在晚上 10 点到凌晨 5 点之间写下了他的畅销书。
  • 沃伦·巴菲特以每天喝五罐可口可乐而闻名。
  • 等等 …

没有任何秘密饮食、锻炼、冥想或日记练习可以让你成功。沃伦·巴菲特之所以富有，并不是因为他的垃圾食品饮食。他之所以富有，是因为他是一位技术精湛的投资者，连续工作了近八年。

真正推动职业成功的因素是什么

看，每天冥想、找到最有效率的工作时间或喝可乐并没有什么错。 （好吧，也许最后一个不太好……）

相反，我对此类建议的疑虑在于，它关注的是最多与一个人的职业成功间接相关的行为。也许雷·达里奥是对的，冥想让他更有效率——或者也许他真的很擅长成为一名对冲基金经理。

分析顶尖员工成功的驱动因素的一个更好的方法是检查他们的职业资本。这些是他们拥有的直接为其雇主、客户或消费者创造价值的资产：

  1. 技能。如果你能做很少有人能做的工作，或者你能比大多数人做得更好，那么你在找工作时就有了强大的讨价还价的筹码。拥有稀有且有价值的技能的人可以在谈判中引发竞标战，而普通技能水平平庸的人通常不能。
  2. 连接。人际关系也可以是一种资产。一位职业生涯较长的记者经常能获得一本书的交易，不仅因为她花了多年的时间磨练自己的写作技巧，还因为她认识出版界的很多人可以谈论她的书。
  3. 名声。您如何选择购买哪些产品？您很可能不会购买所有可能的选项并在家中进行测试，然后再退回除您最喜欢的选项之外的所有选项。您不必依赖评论，而是选择价格范围内优质的品牌并询问您认识的人。当人们雇用你时也是如此。

职业资本以偶然的习惯无法解释的方式解释成功。虽然很容易找到将自己的成功归因于特定行为怪癖的人的例子，但也很容易找到很多具有相同行为的人没有取得如此成功的案例。

相比之下，如果一个人的职业生涯很成功，那么他们几乎肯定拥有大量的职业资本。

如何建立职业资本

职业资本有不同的形式，我们已经讨论过三种：技能、人脉和声誉。

在这些资产中，技能往往是第一位的。 1

如果你出生在富裕家庭，或者就读于精英私立学校并拥有良好的人际网络，那么人脉关系会很好。但如果你不这样做，那么随机敲开成功人士的大门，希望他们成为你的朋友并帮助你，就不是大多数人能够实现的策略。

更常见的是，良好的工作会带来联系。当你因在自己的工作领域表现出色而出名时，人们就会想了解你。

同样，声誉往往比原始能力更重要。但是，与人脉关系一样，声誉是出色工作的自然副产品。声誉取决于技能，而不是相反。

技能还具有可训练的好处。虽然漂亮的外表、家庭财富或名人朋友可能是宝贵的职业资产，但如果你不偶然发现它们，它们并不总是可用的。

任何人都可以提高自己的技能组合，从而改善他们的职业生涯。

与卡尔·纽波特和我一起在最佳表现者中建立职业资本

在过去的八年里，我和卡尔·纽波特一直在开办一门名为“最佳表演者”的私人课程，帮助人们培养适合其工作的稀有而宝贵的技能。如果您有兴趣建立真正推动职业成功的资产（并忽略那些无助于事业成功的资产），我们希望您能参加下周开始的下一次会议。

; https://www.scothyoung.com/blog/2023/09/10/warren-buffett-lunch/feed/ 0 效率思维https://www.scothyoung.com/blog/2023/08/29/efficiency-mindset/ https://www.scothyoung.com/blog/2023/08/29/efficiency-mindset/#respondScott Young Tue, 29 Aug 2023 16:15:00 +0000General https://www.scothyoung.com/blog/?p=15340

懒惰什么时候才算聪明？为什么提高工作效率背后的想法常常让人感觉我们被欺骗了，需要更多地工作？

《效率心态》一文首先出现在Scott H Young上。

;

我们最深的信念常常受到我们很少阐明的假设的约束。效率的心态是我的心态之一。

这种心态的假设本质上是：

  1. 有些东西是我们想要的。
  2. 我们可以采取行动来得到我们想要的东西。
  3. 有些行动比其他行动更有效——也就是说，他们会用更少的时间、精力、金钱等得到更多我们想要的东西。
  4. 我们通过提高效率节省的资源可以用于我们想要的其他事情。

考虑一个具体的例子，想象一个像考试学习这样的任务：

  1. 您想要一件事：通过考试并学习材料。
  2. 您可以采取一些行动来获得您想要的东西：学习。
  3. 有些行为比其他行为更有效：某些学习方法比其他方法能带来更多的学习效果。
  4. 如果您使用更有效的方法来节省考试学习时间，您就可以将这些时间用于您喜欢的其他活动。

效率思维广泛适用，因为这些假设适用于很多事情。但注意它们在哪里崩溃也很重要。

效率思维在哪里崩溃了？

对效率思维模式的常见批评源于对假设#1（你想要的东西）过于狭隘的解释。

考虑快速阅读一本小说。这是“高效”的，因为您可以在更短的时间内读完这本书。但这真的是你想要的吗？

阅读小说的大部分价值来自于享受情节、沉浸在人物的世界中，或者思考书的深层含义。

当效率经常失败时，通常是因为我们对活动的价值采取了过于严格、不完整或不准确的看法。

虽然这是应用效率思维模式的一个难题，但这并不是一个令人信服的反对它的论据。如果你将所有你看重的东西结合起来，并适当加权，那么效率思维仍然有效。在考虑阅读小说的效率时，必须包括“享受”和其他经常被忽视的价值观。

效率的真正失败并不是我们所期望的过于狭隘的概念，而是当假设#4，即你可以对通过提高效率节省下来的资源进行再投资时，这个假设就被打破了。

当更努力工作只会创造更多工作时

效率思维的核心是通过效率节省的时间或资源是可以替代的。你需要能够将做一件事所节省的时间、金钱或精力应用到其他事情上。如果你不能对资源进行再投资，那么更高效地做事也不会获得回报。

十几岁的时候，一个夏天我在一家录像带租赁店工作。在商店里提高工作效率是毫无意义的。老板会劝告员工利用空闲时间清理货架或整理陈列架，但人们很少这么做。店里不忙的时候，我们就闲逛。当有任务要做时，没有人急于尽快完成。

没有人（也许除了经理）考虑效率这一事实是完全有道理的。更加努力的工作并没有得到回报。我们的工作时间是固定的，我们赚取最低工资，并且没有额外努力的绩效奖金。没有人谋求晋升或希望在视频租赁公司的阶梯上晋升。如果你提前完成工作，那么工作只会更加忙碌。节省下来的时间你无法做任何更有趣的事情。

此外，在那种环境下，提高工作效率会带来社会成本。与其他员工一起出去玩是这份无心工作中唯一的快乐，所以如果你成为快速完成所有事情的人，你会让你的其他同事看起来很糟糕。

我确信管理层的观点是我们都只是懒惰。我们得到报酬是为了在那里工作，那么为什么我们不尽可能努力地工作呢？但从我们的角度来看，只要满足实际的工作要求，就没有理由提高效率。

我有时会想起那些日子，因为我现在的生活是天壤之别。我是我自己的老板，我的收入、空闲时间和个人成功完全取决于我的效率。然而，我也意识到，如果你习惯了没有理由提高效率的环境，那么“效率”只是老板希望你做的事情的代名词。

效率是一个新概念

我之所以提到这段经历，是因为在人类历史上不同的文化和社会组织中，我认为为提高效率而付出代价的情况相对较少。

我现在找不到来源，但我记得读过一本书，西方研究人员来调查一个从事自给农业的偏远部落。接受调查的部落居民经常抱怨饥饿，想要更多食物。但是，在调查员看来，他们似乎，嗯……有点懒。他们并没有做人类学家看来显而易见的事情，只是种植更多农作物，以便有更多食物。

作者声称这与他们所居住的社会组织有关。假设你确实种植了过剩的食物，你就可以想吃多少就吃多少。但在你生活的这个紧密团结的乐队里，分享是必要的。所以远方的亲戚饿了就会抱怨你给他们一些食物。勤劳的自给自足的农民不会有太多的动力去努力工作，因为任何剩余都可能被拿走。

由于这开始听起来像是一个隐藏的自由主义寓言，我认为值得指出的是，即使在拥有强大的社会福利国家和进步的再分配政策的社会中，我们仍然可以保留大部分劳动成果。

相反，我想说的是，效率带来的好处是现代社会的一个相当不寻常的特征，而且在大多数时候，我们可能就像那些“懒惰”的自给自足的农民一样，看不到这一点。变得更有效率。如果效率对我们来说似乎不自然，那可能是因为，在我们的整个进化史上，努力工作以产生盈余通常并不是一个明智的策略。

是你懒惰，还是你的工作场所如此？

我们工作的大多数环境都存在一定的范围。一方面是没有出路的视频租赁工作或部落自给自足的农民，在这些地方，效率的想法是陌生的，而且没有回报。另一个极端是过于注重效率的情况，因为任何收益都是个人奖励。

工作文化也存在不同的范围。我之前讨论过对日本办公室文化的有趣描述，这种文化似乎很重视在办公室极端工作时间（结果是员工的效率往往非常低下）。另一个极端是只注重结果的工作环境，其中薪酬完全取决于绩效（但绩效可能很难公平地跟踪和评估）。

我怀疑，当生产力感觉像是一件苦差事而不是一个机会时，这不是因为我们本质上很懒，而是因为我们的环境使我们如此。

对过去一年和未来一年的一些生日反思。

帖子“我 35 岁”首先出现在Scott H Young上。

;

今天是我的生日。按照我现在已经做了一半的传统，这篇文章回顾了我过去一年的生活以及我对未来一年的想法。

去年是重要的一年。我庆祝了我的第二个孩子朱莉娅的出生。我完成了第二本书《在任何事情上都变得更好》的手稿，该书将于 2024 年春季出版。我们也在新房子里度过了第一年，我们是在我上一次生日前不久搬进来的。

在生孩子的同时完成一本书让我很忙。最初的几个月是一种同步的混乱。我习惯了起床、送孩子去托儿所、去办公室写一整天、回家、做饭、打扫卫生、哄儿子上床睡觉，然后昏迷过去几个小时的断断续续的睡眠的节奏。 。 1

尽管如此，我发现今年自己的压力比去年要小。现实很少反映我们的预期。完成这项工作的压力比想象的要小——尤其是当我写了更多的章节并且对它的进展越来越有信心时。

到五月，我交了手稿，朱莉娅达到了她三个月的里程碑，带来了一个相对轻松的夏天。我周五休息，以便有更多时间在家陪伴孩子。我什至设法做了一些绘画和素描——这是已经中断了几年的事情。

Plans for Next Year

Aside from publishing the book, I have a few things I want to work on next year.

One is to do more of my weekly writing ahead of schedule. While I find essay writing enjoyable, the task has grown since my more informal days years ago. Now, each piece goes through multiple edits, I often do illustrations, and we record podcast and YouTube versions .

The weekly essay writing of the blog isn't a full-time job, but it's not trivial either. It tends to absorb a lot of time. This effect is compounded by having kids—even weekends at home can feel incredibly busy. Thus, one experiment I have for the next year is to batch more of my writing so I can deliberately cultivate some longer stretches to work on new projects.

Another goal is to travel more. Between the pandemic and having two small kids, I haven't traveled as much as I'd like. But I agree with Tyler Cowen, who sees travel as an essential part of his work, not just leisure. Writing for a worldwide audience is hard if you're always stuck at home.

Finally, I'd like to rebuild some exercise habits that atrophied in the last year. Firmly in my thirties now, I feel there are greater costs to my health and energy levels from having bad habits compared to when I was younger. Since busyness is ever present, just going to the gym “when I have time” is chronically insufficient.

The Path Ahead

Figuring out what I want to do with my life has never been a single decision. Instead, it's always been a constant back-and-forth of pursuing new directions and recommitting to old ones.

One struggle I've had professionally has been navigating to a more mature phase of my work. When writing Ultralearning , I knew I was documenting a phase of my life that was nearing a close. I will never stop learning new things, but my life was already shifting away from that style of big, bold, public-facing projects. While I have zero regrets about those earlier efforts, I don't really have the desire to try to repeatedly one-up myself or iterate endless variations of the same challenge.

After Ultralearning , I considered the path of being a serial author. The success of my first book gave me the opportunity to write another. While I'm pleased with how the book ended up, the difficulty of the writing process makes me hesitant of planning to churn out a new book ever year or two.

Going back to do a Ph.D. has also been an option I've toyed around with for years. Given that much of my writing has come to rely on academic research, my own lack of credentials may put a limit on my reach at some point. But I've also found the bureaucracy and specialization of academia somewhat alienating, so at this point, I'm happy being a dilettante.

Ultimately, the path I end up taking will probably not be entirely premeditated. Instead, it will be a by-product of smaller experiments—writing things I like to read and working on projects I think are interesting. I'm forever grateful for the luxury of being able to take risks like this—something I owe to the readers who have continued to follow my work!

Following my mind-is-a-computer essay, I cover seven other popular-among-experts-but-widely-disbelieved opinions I agree with!

The post 7 Expert Opinions I Agree With (That Most People Don't) appeared first on Scott H Young .

;

Recently, I wrote a defense of the uncontroversial-within-cognitive-science-but-widely-disbelieved idea that the mind is a computer .

That post got me thinking about other ideas that are broadly accepted amongst the expert communities that study them, but not among the general population. 1

I agreed with some of the following ideas before I read much about them; for these, the expert consensus reinforced my prior worldview. But for most, I had to be persuaded. Many ideas are genuinely surprising, and one needs to be confronted with a lot of evidence before changing their mind about it.

1. Markets are mostly efficient. Most people, most of the time, cannot “beat” the market.

The efficient market hypothesis argues that the price of widely-traded securities, like stocks, reflects an aggregation of all available information about them. This means investors can't spot “deals” or “overpriced” assets and use that knowledge to outperform the average market return (without taking on more risk).

The mechanism underlying this is simple: Suppose you did have information that an asset was mispriced. You'd be incentivized to buy or short the asset, expecting a better return than the current market would dictate. But this action causes the asset's price to adjust in the opposite direction, moving it closer to the “correct” value. Taken as a whole, the very action of investors trying to beat the market is what makes it so difficult to beat.

Asset bubbles and stock market crashes are not good evidence against this view. (Of all the people who “predicted” a bubble/crash, how many made money from their prediction?) Nor is that friend you know who seemingly made fantastic returns from crypto/real estate/penny stocks/etc. (That's usually explained by them taking on more risk, and thus having a higher risk premium, and getting lucky.)

The obvious consequence is that for most retail investors, it's best to put their money in broad-based index funds to get the benefits of diversification and earn the average market return with few fees.

2. Intelligence is real, important, largely heritable, and not particularly changeable.

This is one that I fought accepting for years. It goes against my beliefs in the value of self-cultivation, practice and learning. However, the evidence is overwhelming :

  • Intelligence is one of the most scientifically valid psychometric measurements (far more so than personality, including the dubious Myers Briggs ).
  • It is positively correlated with many other things we want in life (including happiness, longevity and income!).
  • It shows strong heritability, with the g-factor maybe being as much as 85% heritable.
  • Finally, few interventions reliably improve IQ, with a possible exception for more education (although it's not clear this improves g).

I don't like trotting this argument out. I find it much more appealing to believe in a world where IQ tests don't measure anything, or they don't measure anything important, or that any differences are due to education and environment, or that you could improve your intelligence through hard work.

That said, I do think there's a silver lining here. While your general intelligence may not be easy to change, there's ample evidence that gaining knowledge and skills improves your ability to do all sorts of tasks. Practically speaking, the best way to become smarter is to learn a lot of stuff and cultivate a lot of skills. Since knowledge and skills are more specific than general intelligence, that may be less than we desire, but it still matters a lot.

3. Learning styles aren't real. There's no such thing as being a “kinesthetic,” “visual,” or “auditory” learner.

I've had multiple interviews for my book, Ultralearning , where the host asks me to talk about learning styles. And I always have to, ever so gently, explain that they don't exist.

The theory of learning styles is an eminently testable hypothesis:

  • Give people a survey or test to see what their learning style is.
  • Teach the same subject in different ways (diagrams, verbal description, physical model) that either correspond with or go against a person's style.
  • See whether they perform better when teaching matches their learning style and worse when it doesn't.

Careful experiments don't find the performance enhancements one would expect based on the theory. Ergo, learning styles isn't a good theory .

I think part of why this idea survives is that (a) people love the psychological equivalent of horoscopes—this may be why Myers Briggs is so popular despite a lack of scientific support for it as a theory. And, (b) that some people are simply better at visualizing, listening or more dexterous is a truism that seems quite similar to learning styles. But just because you're better at basketball than math doesn't mean you'll learn calculus better if the teacher tries to explain it in terms of three-pointers.

4. The world around us is explained entirely by physics.

Sean Carroll articulates a basic physicist worldview that quantum mechanics and the physics described by the Standard Model essentially explain everything around us.

The remaining controversies of physics, from string theory to supersymmetry, are primarily theoretical issues only relevant at extremely high energies. For everyday life at room temperature, the physics we already know does remarkably well at making predictions.

True, knowing the Standard Model doesn't help us predict most of the big things we care about—even calculating the effects of interactions between a few particles can be intractable. But, in principle, everything from democratic governance to the beauty of sunsets is contained in those equations.

5. People are overweight because they eat too much. It is also really hard to stop.

The calorie-in, calorie-out model is, thermodynamically speaking, correct. People who are overweight would lose weight if they ate less.

Yet, this is really difficult to do. As I discuss with neuroscientist and obesity researcher Stephan Guyenet , your brain has specific neural circuitry designed to avoid starvation and, by extension, any rapid weight-loss. When you lose a lot of body fat, your hunger levels increase to encourage you to bring it back up.

This is hardly a radical view, but it's strongly opposed by a particularly noisy segment of online opinion that either tries to explain weight in terms of something other than calories or, conceding that, seems to assert that the problem is simply a matter of applying a little effort.

One reason I'm optimistic about the new class of weight-loss drugs is simply that, as a society, we're probably heavier than is optimally healthy, and most interventions based on willpower don't work.

6. Children don't learn languages faster than adults, but they do reach higher levels of mastery.

Common wisdom says if you're going to learn a language, learn it early. Children regularly become fluent in their home and classroom language, indistinguishable from native speakers; adults rarely do.

But even if children eventually surpass the attainments of adults in pronunciation and syntax, it's not true that children learn faster. Studies routinely find that, given the same form of instruction/immersion, older learners tend to become proficient in a language more quickly than children do—adults simply plateau at a non-native level of ability, given continued practice.

I take this as evidence that language learning proceeds through both a fast, explicit channel and a slow, implicit channel. Adults and older children may have a more fully developed fast channel, but perhaps have deficiencies in the slow channel that prevent completely native-like acquisition.

This implies that if you want your child to be completely bilingual, it helps to start early. But that probably requires non-trivial amounts of immersive time in the second language. If they're only going to a weekly class the way most adults learn, then there may be no special benefit to starting extremely young and maybe even an advantage to starting older.

7. We're better off than our grandparents. We're vastly better off than our ancestors.

Economic pessimism is fashionable.

Everyone I talk to likes to point out various ways that the current generation (at least in North America, where I reside) has it worse than our parents did: houses and college degrees costs cost more, and it is harder to support a family on a single earner's paycheck.

But pretty much every economic indicator is positive . Even the indicators that pessimistic pundits like to complain about are largely from areas where wages have been stagnant, or inequality has been rising rather than genuine decline.

The world we live in today is wealthier than that of our parents, and fantastically wealthier than it was a century ago. Economic progress is not everything, but it matters a great deal.

This isn't a call to stop striving and rest on our laurels; many problems in society still require fixing. But a narrative that begins by denying the material progress that has genuinely been made distorts the task ahead of us.

An analysis into a prevalent cognitive illusion about the nature of success in many fields.

The post Why I'm Not More Popular appeared first on Scott H Young .

;

Recently, when I was a guest on a podcast, the host asked me why my book wasn't more popular. She thought it belonged in the same class as mega-bestsellers like Atomic Habits or Deep Work , and was surprised it wasn't in the same league for popularity.

While it's deeply flattering to be told your work is underrated, I think some people's surprise that a moderately-popular thing isn't super popular stems from a cognitive illusion.

Why Bestsellers Seem Common

Try to imagine every book you've ever read, seen or heard about. How many books would that be?

Maybe 1000?

It's probably not more than 10,000 unless you're an avid bibliophile or work in publishing.

Now try to guess how many books are actually written. For published books, estimates range from 500,000 to one million books are published every year. Including self-published books, and it's closer to four million. The Library of Congress has 32 million cataloged books, which is an undercount of every book ever written.

That means every book you've heard about, let alone read, makes up less than 0.00003% of all the books that exist!

Furthermore, the books you've heard about are not a randomly-selected sample. the likelihood you've heard of a book corresponds fairly closely with its popularity in the general marketplace. The average traditionally-published book typically sells a few thousand copies in its lifetime. In contrast, mega-bestsellers sell tens of millions.

Thus the picture the average reader gets of the market looks like this:

But the reality of publishing is actually this:

The handful of people who (ever-so-kindly) think I'm underrated are probably thinking of a dozen or so popular books of the same genre. Owing to the biases mentioned above, these examples are disproportionately drawn from the pool of enormously successful books. They notice that my book is less successful than that elite cohort and find it surprising.

These people are missing the hundreds of thousands of books similar to mine in quality (or better!) that they've never heard of because they aren't bestsellers!

This analysis applies to any kind of creative work. We watch famous YouTubers with millions of subscribers and ignore the vast majority who have less than a thousand. We hear about research done by elite scientists from Harvard and MIT, but not work by ordinary academics. Music, movies, journalism, athletics and countless other fields suffer from the same distortion.

I'm intensely grateful to have achieved a place where people buy my book and I get invited to be on podcasts. Most people don't get this much, even those whose work deserves it.

What About Quality? Don't Better Books Sell More?

Of course, books that become bestsellers aren't entirely random. I've been envious of James Clear's writing ability since before he wrote Atomic Habits , so it wasn't surprising to me when his book became a major hit. He's a thoughtful and engaging writer.

While there are snobs who argue that a book's popularity is a sign of low quality, I think this take reflects particular tastes rather than describing a general feature of the mass market. 1

However, even if you try to argue that popularity is perfectly correlated with underlying writing quality, the two scales differ by orders of magnitude.

If writing quality exists on a scale from 1 to 100, book sales range from zero to tens of millions. 2 Thus, even in a world where writing quality perfectly predicts sales, it is still unfair. Those who are ever-so-slightly better can reap hundreds or thousands of times the rewards.

Almost no one believes that a book's quality is perfectly predictive of its success. Books succeed in part because of quality, but also because of random factors that neither the author nor an outside observer could easily predict. Those who become phenomenal bestsellers are often just as surprised as anyone that their book has taken off.

What Level of Success Should You Expect?

At its heart, this suggests a rather pessimistic downgrading of our ability to succeed in fields like book publishing. If we're greatly exaggerating the proportion of books that become bestsellers, we're implicitly overestimating our odds of success.

I think there is some truth to this.

Success at an extreme level is usually the overlap of many competing factors, only some of which are in your control. If your personal definition of success or happiness depends on being in a rarefied elite, this analysis should chasten you to the reality of that goal.

Even if you're pursuing more modest success, however, thinking this way can help you do better. When success is much rarer than you think, you need to pay close attention to what works , work hard to master the fundamental skills of your craft, and ensure you're committed to making it work.

Having achieved modest popularity, I'm thankful for everyone who enjoys my work. Whether you think my work is underrated or overrated, I'm endlessly grateful for the opportunity to write about things I find interesting for a living.

I defend the view that the mind is a computer, and why people who devote their lives to studying the brain believe it.

The post The Mind is a Computer appeared first on Scott H Young .

;

In my recent call for questions , a reader asked me a version of Peter Thiel's now-famous interview question : what important truth do few people agree with you on?

I had a hard time answering this because, for the most part, I'm an intellectual conformist. I read what experts think and generally agree with their consensus.

While intellectual conformity may sound cowardly, I'd argue it's actually a kind of virtue. My professional incentives align with being contrarian rather than dryly repeating whatever Wikipedia says on a topic.

I usually agree with experts because experts are regular people who have learned a lot about a topic. If regular people tend to coalesce around a certain worldview after hearing all the evidence, it's probably because that worldview is more likely to be correct! 1

A side-effect of this habit is that conforming to experts' thinking sometimes puts you wildly out of step with most other people.

Non-expert opinions often sharply diverge from how experts see a subject. So when you read a lot about a topic, and your opinion converges with the typical expert view, it can diverge from the commonsense view of reality. 2

Consider the idea that the mind is a kind of computer.

This is the central assumption of cognitive science and represents an orthodox view within psychology and neuroscience. There are caveats and dissenters, to be sure. Still, faith in the information-processing paradigm of the mind is far more prevalent among people who spend their entire lives studying it than the average person on the street.

Why the Mind is a Kind of Computer

The classic rhetorical trick amongst skeptics of this view is to point out the history of analogies for the brain. The ancient Greeks saw the mind as a chariot pulled by horses of reason and emotion. RenÃ© Descartes viewed the brain as a system of hydraulics. Every age, it is argued, has fumbled for the best metaphor for the brain and ours is no different. Just as the idea that pressurized fluids manage the brain seems silly today, so will a future era see the computer analogy as quaint.

But there is good reason to think the computer analogy is different.

This is not because brains are literally similar to a laptop. Instead, it is because computer science has discovered that computation is a relatively abstract property, and many completely different physical devices share the same constraints and powers.

Alan Turing and Alonzo Church each independently discovered that the former's Turing Machine , a hypothetical instrument that followed instructions on an infinite ticker tape, and the latter's Lambda Calculus , a mathematical language, were formally equivalent. Since then, many seemingly unrelated systems have been proved formally equivalent—from Conway's Game of Life to the Magic: The Gathering card game .

The extended Church-Turing thesis argues that this isn't a coincidence. Any physical device, whether a brain, laptop or quantum computer, broadly has the same powers and constraints. 3

Saying computers are “just a metaphor” for the mind is misleading because it restricts computers to the Von Neumann architecture used in silicon computers today. But the abstract concept of a physical device that processes information is much broader and more powerful. The heart differs from a bicycle pump, but is obviously a member of the abstract class of “pumping machines.” In the same way, the brain is quite different from a laptop, but they're both members of the abstract class of “information-processing machines.”

The point isn't to elide any difference between the digital computers we manufacture and the biological computers we're born with. Instead, it's to recognize that if you wanted to understand the heart but were somehow philosophically opposed to thinking of it as a kind of pump, you would have a hard time making sense of how it works.

But What Kind of Computer?

Saying the brain is a kind of computer is like saying bacteria and people are both organisms. The latter is also uncontroversial within biology today, even though the idea would have seemed fantastical two-hundred years ago. At the same time, bacteria and people are different.

Clearly, the brain differs in many ways from the transistor-based computers we are familiar with:

  • The brain is far more complicated. The human brain has ~100 billion neurons. Each individual neuron has sophisticated computational properties that can require a supercomputer to model. While a bacteria and a human differ in more than just size, the scale of things is a significant distinction. Bigger is different .
  • The brain is massively parallel and interconnected, having as many as a quadrillion synapses. Modern computers have a serial architecture where computation goes through a central processing unit. 4 In contrast, brains distribute the calculations across the entire neural network. This difference changes the algorithms that can be used, which is why human thinking is qualitatively different from computer code.
  • Bodies have sensory inputs and motor outputs that interact with our environment. The human brain has billions of sensory cells and billions of motor effectors, each of which engages in feedback loops with the environment. This is a major contrast with most human-built computer systems which are essentially detached from the world except for small windows of input and output.

These differences aren't trivial. But, just as a single bacterium and a human being are both organisms, I think it's worth stressing that even these great differences don't alter the fundamental truth that the mind is a type of computer.

What About Meaning, Emotions and Subjectivity?

Within psychology and neuroscience, the dominant controversies are over what kind of computer the mind is rather than whether or not it computes. But I think the more typical objection to this viewpoint from people outside those fields is a humanistic one. Essentially, the objections are:

  • Computers are logical; humans are emotional. The cognitive scientist would counter that emotions are a kind of computation. Motivation, attention, fear, happiness and curiosity are all important functional properties. While the nature of the algorithm isn't transparent to us via introspection, this is broadly true of all of our cognitive processes.
  • Computers aren't sentient; humans have consciousness. I agree with Daniel Dennett that philosophical ideas like qualia , p-zombies or the impossibility of knowing what it is like to be a bat are misleading intuitions. The “hard” problem of consciousness-as-subjectivity is a confusion, not a genuine puzzle. In contrast, while the “easy” problem is still unsolved, there's been considerable headway in explaining how consciousness-as-awareness works .
  • Computers are rule-governed; human thinking is holistic. Hubert Dreyfus famously made this argument against the computer analogy back when the serial-computer model was more prevalent in artificial intelligence. However, I think the “what kind of computer?” framework above largely resolves this issue. Presumably, the brain's sheer quantity of processors and enormous parallel activity explain the powers (and limitations) of intuition and holistic thinking.
  • Who are we to think we can “understand” the soul? The final objection is simply an appeal to mysticism. I'm not principally against this—if you'd prefer to dwell in the mystery of life rather than try to figure things out, that's a reasonable choice. But obviously, it's the antithesis of the aims of science.

We know less about how the mind works than we know about, say, microbiology. But, just as vitalism was proved false and life really is just chemistry, I'm convinced the mind really is just a computer and that the ongoing scientific project of figuring out how it works is one of the most exciting pursuits of our time.

I respond to reader questions regarding procrastination, language learning, depression and more.

The post Reader Mailbag (Part II): Overcoming Procrastination, the Input Hypothesis, Time Management and Motor Skills appeared first on Scott H Young .

;

Two weeks ago, I asked the audience to send me their questions. The response was great, so I decided to split my responses over two posts. You can see last week's answers here , where I talked about Range , learning styles, nootropics and the value of learning things you're doomed to forget.

Some questions have been lightly edited, and questions that multiple people asked have been merged into single questions.

Q: How can I overcome procrastination?

(multiple readers)

The research on procrastination indicates that we mainly fail to buckle down and get to work (or our studies) because we find the task unpleasant, and putting it off is more immediately rewarding than getting to work.

This seems a pretty banal observation, but it's important to note what it excludes. The research does not, for instance, find that perfectionism is strongly associated with procrastination (something widely believed). Nor is anxiety clearly associated with more procrastination (if you're anxious, you might even work harder!).

In terms of overcoming procrastination, I think this is why developing a productivity system—some kind of guiding framework that tells you what to work on and when—is so valuable. Over time, if you stick to the system, the decision of what to work on gets delegated to that system, and you learn to abide by it. That alone eliminates a lot of excessive procrastination.

However, I think it's also important to point out that procrastination is often useful! Our motivational hardware is designed to balance many competing interests and needs. A person pathologically incapable of procrastinating would also likely be willing to stick out working on a lot of tedious, low-value tasks.

While we want to keep our procrastination to an adaptive (rather than maladaptive) level, you should also embrace some of it as your motivational system functioning properly.

Q: What do you think of Stephen Krashen's Input Hypothesis?

(multiple readers)

Krashen's Input Hypothesis is an influential (and controversial) language learning theory arguing that exposure to lots of language you can understand is both necessary and sufficient to achieve completely fluency in a language.

Additionally, Krashen has argued for a distinction between learning a language and acquiring a language, arguing that languages cannot be practiced (thus, there's no value in encouraging people to speak a language), nor can they be taught (thus, there's no value in explaining grammar or correcting people's mistakes).

Judging from the sidelines, I'm somewhat baffled by the theory's popularity. Consider:

  • For most skills, instruction tends to outperform unguided learning. The literature reviews for language learning show… the same thing ? Yet this evidence is dismissed by proponents of Krashen's view as evidencing “learning” and not “acquisition.”
  • People in input-only learning environments tend not to acquire native-level productive fluency in a language. This suggests that the speaking part of immersive learning isn't superfluous.
  • Adults and adolescents over the age of 10-14 rarely achieve completely native proficiency in a language, despite decades of full-time exposure. Krashen's theory attributes this to an “affective filter” that prevents pure input from working its magic. It seems implausible to me that this can explain the near-universal success of six-year-olds in acquiring their native language but exceedingly rare odds of twenty-six-year-olds in achieving native-level pronunciation and grammar.
  • We already have a good idea of how we acquire implicit, fluent knowledge in other skills. Why would those same laws of skill acquisition not also apply to language learning? Even if there are language-specific mechanisms, it seems likely that adult language learners can also benefit from skill-learning systems.

Outside of academic circles, Krashen's theory mainly influences language learners who prefer to read and listen as their primary method for learning instead of practicing conversation.

Despite my preferred approach , I'm not against such approaches. Given that opportunities to speak a foreign language can be limited, you probably can go quite far just by reading and listening a lot. Even so, I think some speaking practice and formal instruction are also helpful for most learners.

Q: I find myself struggling with anxiety/depression, and it makes it harder to work on my key goals.我应该怎么办？

(multiple readers)

My first suggestion in all these situations is that if you're struggling with obsessive, negative thoughts, seek therapy if you can, particularly therapists that work with cognitive-behavioral therapy , as it tends to have the greatest empirical support.

CBT tends to perform similarly to pharmaceutical treatments (which also seem to work well, so many people benefit from both). The basic idea behind CBT is that we can get into recurring patterns of thinking, feeling and action that mutually reinforce.

For instance, a person with social anxiety might have unpleasant feelings about going to a party. This triggers vivid imaginings about what might go wrong (maybe they say the wrong thing and embarrass themselves). The anxiety builds until they cancel the invitation and stay home. That causes some momentary relief, but it reinforces the thought and behavior patterns that led to that avoidance and entrenches the anxiety further.

Learning to notice and disable those patterns can be a major step to reducing their grip on you. If you cannot access therapy, I recommend reading more about cognitive-behavioral approaches so you can get the gist of what the work might look like.

Still, I'm not a clinical psychologist, so what I say is not medical advice and ought to be taken with a grain of salt.

Q: What do you think is a more effective approach: managing your day by tasks or managing your day by time/schedule?

– Tavan

I used to be a wholehearted advocate of the task-based approach: Make a daily to-do list and work on it until it's finished.

The benefit of the task-based method is that it focuses on getting work done. I find it works well when you have a bunch of predictable tasks that need doing, there's no pressing need to “do more” toward your projects, and you may have a strong urge to procrastinate. Ending when your tasks are done creates an incentive to get everything done so you can enjoy the rest of your day.

However, this approach can struggle when the projects you're working on are open-ended, or the tasks you're trying to work on are hard to predict in advance. In those cases, I rely on a fixed-schedule approach to productivity.

I think the issue of productivity systems is that there probably isn't a good universal system. Instead, different approaches work better or worse, given your typical tasks and goals. As a college student, I found the task-based system worked well. But I find it breaks down in other environments. Similarly, Cal Newport's time-blocking system works well when you're intensely busy and have many appointments on your calendar, but it may feel like overkill if you can get your work done without it.

Q: I am curious to learn more about how blocking eyes might affect motor skill learning. A piano player or tennis player that do drills blindfolded or with one eye covered.

– Ola

I'm not sure! My understanding of the motor skills literature is somewhat weaker than other aspects of educational psychology.

I know that when I was learning to touch type, we taped a sheet of paper at the top of the keyboard and typed underneath to prevent us from looking at the keys. That encourages you to look at the document you're transcribing and memorize the key positions directly. However, many other skills seem innately coupled to a visual/kinesthetic feedback loop, so doing it blindfolded would likely cause performance to deteriorate for an unclear purpose (I wouldn't ski down a mountain blindfolded, for instance).

I can say that introducing novel constraints is often a good way to “shift” a motor pattern into a new equilibrium that would be hard to achieve through conscious effort alone. There's interesting research showing that people tend to acquire movement skills better when they focus their attention on the goal of a movement rather than the movement itself. This suggests clever constraints may be beneficial to shift you out of a bad habit.
